That if we care about the environment at all (and heck, maybe some people don't), then an alternative to PoW-based mining is the only option. Renewable energy is a possibility, but it's never going to be cost-free or completely free of environmental impact.

Bitcoin mining is literally a few large companies competing over who can spend the most $$$ burning electricity. All PoW-based consensus with profit potential leads to this eventuality. Anyone telling you otherwise is selling snake oil.pic.twitter.com/w8UgurOqJy

A lot of people don't understand the dynamics of PoW mining - they're actually rather simple. "More efficient mining algorithms" do not end the arms race or associated electricity burned.https://twitter.com/ummjackson/status/997230046485008384 …
PoW mining = entities competing to deploy the most capital ($) for a chance to win a block. Burning electricity is the unfortunate proxy for how that capital is deployed.

Even if the algorithms become more efficient to mine (which is what ASICs essentially do, btw), then the competition just increases and people need to build better ASICs and still burn more electricity ($$$) than the other miners to get the block reward + fees.
So you're burning a finite resource that costs money (electricity) in order to secure the network. There is no way you can continue to secure the network if it becomes free to do so.
Anyone who sells the notion that PoW mining "just needs to be more efficient" is selling snake oil. The very premise of PoW mining working is that it's costly IRL to produce said work.

This doesn't even factor in mining of other PoW currencies such as Ethereum, Zcash etc. The energy consumption numbers are even higher.
